content.description:
Researchers investigated the influence of environmental <math alttext="p H" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>pH</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> on the activity of peroxidase, an enzyme that catalyzes the conversion of hydrogen peroxide to water and oxygen gas. In an experiment, the researchers added a hydrogen peroxide solution containing guaiacol to several identical test tubes and adjusted the solution in each test tube to a different <math alttext="p H" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>pH</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. The researchers included the guaiacol because it caused the solutions to change color as the reactions proceeded, which the researchers relied on for measuring reaction rates. Finally, the researchers added the same amount of peroxidase to each test tube and measured the rate of each reaction at <math alttext="23 degrees Celsius" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>23</mtext><mo>°</mo><mtext>C</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. The results of the experiment are represented in Figure 1.

Figure 1. The effect of <math alttext="p H" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow><mtext>pH</mtext></mrow></math> on peroxidase activity
content.question: Which of the following actions will provide a negative control for the investigation?

choices.label: Repeating the experiment at <math alttext="25 degrees Celsius" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>25</mtext><mo>°</mo><mtext>C</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>
Repeating the experiment using twice the amount of hydrogen peroxide
Repeating the experiment using twice the amount of peroxidase
Repeating the experiment using heat-denatured peroxidase

content.answer: Repeating the experiment using heat-denatured peroxidase
